filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of a digital edition of twenty-seven water color drawings produced by Blake between 1775 and c. 1790. Blake’s activities as a water colorist from the mid-1770s through the next decade reveal his increasing skills in that medium, ranging from apprentice work to original compositions exhibited at the Royal Academy. Assignments from his engraving instructor, James Basire, included the precise copying of tomb monuments in Westminster Abbey (Objects 1-5). These water colors were later engraved, probably with Blake’s assistance, as illustrations for Joseph Ayloffe’s Account of Some Ancient Monuments in Westminster Abbey (1780), republished in volume 2 of the Society of Antiquaries’ Vetusta Monumenta (c. 1789). This early contact with Gothic art profoundly affected Blake’s later work as an artist and his writings on the history of art. Shortly after his release from apprenticeship in 1779, Blake began to develop a series of designs picturing major events in the history of England (Objects 7-12). He exhibited one of these, The Death of Earl Goodwin (Object 9) or a more finished version of the design, at the Royal Academy in 1780. This group of pictures may have culminated in “The History of England, a small book of Engravings,” advertised in Blake’s prospectus To the Public in October 1793. Unfortunately, no copy of that work has ever been recorded. Blake developed at least one work in this series, Pestilence, Probably the Great Plague of London (Object 12), into a slightly larger and more finished water color (Object 14). Lear and Cordelia was probably executed as part of the history of England series but is presented in the Archive under Water Color Drawings, Illustrations to Shakespeare. Blake’s early water colors include several designs with biblical subjects (Objects 6, 13, 15, 18, 20-23, 27). The most highly finished and important of these are three illustrations to the story of Joseph and his brethren recounted in Genesis (Objects 20, 22, 23). These were exhibited at the Royal Academy in 1785. One year earlier, Blake’s A Breach in a City, the Morning after the Battle (object 19), had appeared at the same venue. Blake was trying, by the mid-1780s, to establish his reputation as a “history” painter—that is, as a specialist in themes taken from history, the Bible, and canonical literary texts such as Milton’s Paradise Lost. In the eighteenth century, such subjects were believed to be appropriate for the greatest artistic ambitions, but all of Blake’s exhibited works were in water colors rather than the more highly regarded medium of oil painting. Almost all of Blake’s water colors fit comfortably within the long tradition of water color drawing, in which one delineates form by line and the tinting is confined within firm outlines. Water color painting, a style developed by artists such as J. M. W. Turner, allowed for a freer use of washes, unconfined by pen and ink or pencil boundaries and without underlying washes laid in for modeling.

objtitle.title: *King Sebert, Heads and Ornaments from His Monument*

objinfo.medium: pen and ink and water color
objinfo.pennednumbers: noneFragments of the lower part of an inscription, almost completely trimmed off by the top edge of the leaf, appear top right. Butlin 10 records this inscription as "No. 4".

provenance.name: Society of Antiquaries, London
provenance.note: The Society of Antiquaries commissioned Blake's engraving master, James Basire, to execute this drawing. Basire assigned Blake to this task. The drawing was presumably delivered to the Society shortly after its engraving for Joseph Ayloffe, *An Account of Some Ancient Monuments in Westminster Abbey*, first published by the Society of Antiquaries in 1780.

desc.objtitle: King Sebert, Heads and Ornaments from His Monument, Object 1 (Butlin 10)

objnote.p: The collection stamp of the Society of Antiquaries appears lower left just inside the framing lines. A water color replica (Butlin 18) of this water color is in the Bodleian Library, Oxford. An engraving of this design was published in Joseph Ayloffe, *An Account of Some Ancient Monuments in Westminster Abbey*, Plate 6 (1780), and in *Vetusta Monumenta*, volume 2 of c. 1789, Plate 34.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The design collects figureheads and other ornaments featured on the north side of the monument of King Sebert in Westminster Abbey. All three heads have curly hair. The crowns on the two outer figureheads suggest they may be kings. The central head wears a pointed collar and a crown or hat resembling a miter, perhaps representing a bishop. Below the three heads are two crowns, each embellished with leaves. The crown at right (presumably belonging to King Henry III) is slightly taller and may bear gems. Below the crowns, in the center of the design, are pictured two scepter heads. The left, King Sebert's, is a golden Gothic structure. The right, King Henry III's, contains gilded leaves. The four images in the lower half of the design represent details from the kings' apparel or surroundings. First, the top design is featured on the tops of Henry's gloves. It is a red flower or cross surrounded by a diamond shape with four finials at the points. The next two emblems, featured to the left and right below the glove decoration, are details of the borders of the kings' robes. Finally, the center design below these depicts the decorative corner pieces inside Sebert's monument.

component.illusobjdesc: Three figureheads, perhaps made of stone, appear at the top of the design facing forward. The leftmost head has a full face and a cleft chin. Atop his short, curly hair is a crown, which suggests that he may represent a king. The crown bears leaf designs and jewels. A split collar extends below his chin.

Three figureheads, perhaps made of stone, appear at the top of the design facing forward. The shape and headwear of the central head differentiate it from the other two. Below the head extends a large, pointed collar, and atop its short, curly head sits an ornate crown or hat that resembles a miter. This headwear suggests that the figure may represent a bishop.

Three figureheads, perhaps made of stone, appear at the top of the design facing forward. The rightmost figure, similar to king at left, has short, curly hair and wears a crown decorated with crosses and jewels. A split collar appears below his chin.
Below the three heads are two crowns, each embellished with leaves of various sizes. The crown at right (presumably belonging to King Henry III) is slightly taller and may bear gems.
Below the crowns, in the center of the design, are pictured two scepter heads. The scepter head at right, King Henry III's, contains six gilded leaves, the top two of which meet to form a point.

Below the crowns, in the center of the design, are pictured two scepter heads. The left, King Sebert's, is a golden Gothic structure with six pinnacles and corresponding doors or windows. The two center points terminate in finials, the others in rounded toppers.

The four images in the lower half of the design represent details from the kings' apparel or surroundings. First, the top design is featured on the tops of Henry's gloves. It is a red flower or cross superimposed over an "X" and surrounded by a diamond shape with four finials at the points.

The four images in the lower half of the design represent details from the kings' apparel or surroundings. The two emblems featured to the left and right below the glove decoration, are details of the borders of the kings' robes. Sebert's border, on the left, features (from left to right) a row of circles and two narrow lines, a design with finial-pointed arches over flowers, and two more narrow lines. King Henry's border, on the right, has been folded over as it appears in the full portrait. It also features circles and lines near the left edge, but it contains a circle and "X" pattern in the center. The fold is marked with a decorative square, which may hold the robe in place.

The four images in the lower half of the design represent details from the kings' apparel or surroundings. In the lowest center portion of this arrangement is one of the decorative corner pieces supporting the roof inside Sebert's monument. Beveled edges form a corner at upper left, and the exterior points are connected with an arch. The interior of the support features vegetation, perhaps leaves and vines.
The design collects figureheads and other ornaments featured on the north side of the monument of King Sebert in Westminster Abbey.

phystext.p: Heads & Ornaments on the North Side of the Monument of King Sebert, in Westminster Abbey vide Vetust. Mon. Vol. II. plate 34.This pen and ink inscription is probably not by Blake. "Vetust. Mon. Vol. II. plate 34" is a reference to volume 2 of *Vetusta Monumenta*, published by the Society of Antiquaries c. 1789. An engraving of this design, signed by Blake's engraving master James Basire, was published as plate 34 in that volume.
